results.title: Australian Trams in the Sixties. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Reviewing the sights of Australia’s city streets during the swinging ‘60’s brings back all the memories of those wonderful times. This video features Brisbane’s trams from the mid-sixties up until the closure of the system; Flinders and Collins Streets in Melbourne, where we see tramcars; Ballarat, with its mixture of bogie and four wheel cars; Bendigo, for a variety of types including the single truck Birney trams; and the last route to survive in Adelaide’s once extensive system, the Glenelg line.

results.title: Australian trains and tracks
results.brief_description: Jim Downes presents this program which explores the diversity of Australian tracks and trains in the great era of rail transport following World War Two.

results.title: Australian super 8 films 1981-1986
results.brief_description: The early 1980s saw an emergence of a Super 8 film culture. The three hour compilation tape features 27 Super 8 films produced by Australian artists between 1981 and 1986. It attempts to be a representative survey of prominent filmmakers, themes and style. A rare and important documentation of a fertile aspect of Australian film and visual arts activities. Curated by Michael Hutak, Super 8 Group Australia.

results.title: Australian Story: Man For All Seasons: Wayne Bennett
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Vanessa Gorman
results.brief_description:
This is Wayne Bennett’s story, a story of successes and failures, family, good times, challenging times, but most of all, about his passion for the Brisbane Broncos and helping them win more Grand Finals in his 20 years of coaching than any other club in Australian rugby league history. Introduced by Caroline Jones.
Broadcast on ABC TV on 6 May 1999. Reporters/producers include Ben Cheshire, Carolyn Davies, Brigid Donovan, Helen Grasswill, John Millard, Wendy Page.

results.title: Australian story
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
From the ABC television series “Australian Story” comes this compilation of five moving portraits of five very different Australians. Common to all five though is that they are battlers in their own way, overcoming adversity and hardship to live life as best they can. “The Big ‘A’” is about former Prime Minister’s wife Hazel Hawke speaking about her struggle with Alzheimer’s disease. “A Man for all seasons” is the story of revered rugby coach Wayne Bennett. “Boots and all” is about the discovery of a wonderful opera singer in a local shoe-repair shop - Peter Brocklehurst. “About a boy” is the story of young cricket enthusiast Dan Halloran, who grew up with his mother having a mental illness. “On the mountain top” is about Victoria Friend and her survival of a plane crash in remote country Australia.

results.title: Australian steel : progress in Port Kembla
results.brief_description: Iron and steel production at Port Kembla, N.S.W. is linked with quarrying limestone at Iron Monarch and Cockatoo Island, limestones at Marulan and coal mining. A documentary style explanation of processes , products and progression of iron and steel production and coal mining.

results.title: Australian snakes
results.brief_description: A comprehensive survey of the four families of snakes found in Australia: pythons, elapids, colubrids, and typhlops. Highlights differences in colour, size, pattern, habitat and temperament. Narrated by Max Taylor. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
results.description: A comprehensive survey of the four families of snakes found in Australia: pythons, elapids, colubrids, and typhlops. Highlights differences in colour, size, pattern, habitat and temperament. Narrated by Max Taylor. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Australian rules (A) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Premium Movie Partnership, Adelaide Festival Corporation, South Australian Film Corporation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Tidy Town Pictures, Mark Lazarus and Paul Goldman
results.brief_description: Based on the award winning novel “Deadly, unna?” by Phillip Gwynne, “Australian rules” speculates on the deep rooted racism of a small rural fishing community, Prospect Bay, South Australia, where winning the premiership is the most exciting thing to happen since winning a tidy town competition. The film is viewed from the perspective of Blacky/Gary, a quiet, sensitive, and questioning youth who is best friends with football team mate Dumby Red, a brilliant aboriginal footballer and idealist, apparently unaffected by the animosity of older cousin Perry towards the whites. The status quo changes after a farcical grand final presentation in which one of the goonyas (whites) is selected over arguably Best on Ground Dumby. The football field proves the town’s racial arena whereby gunyas (blacks) are tolerated for their superior football prowess - off field, the small minded community is a pressure cooker of racism and hostilities which explode after a tragic event. Blacky’s relationship to Dumby’s sister Clarence also proves a point of contention with his abusive, belligerent and racist father. A thoughtful and passionate film, “Australian rules” was criticised in some sectors for being racist, it is however as much about friendship, intolerance, and life in an isolated community as it is about racism. Cast includes: Nathan Phillips, Luke Carroll, Lisa Flanagan, Tom Budge, Simon Westaway, Celia Ireland, Kevin Harrington. Screenplay by Phillip Gwynne with Paul Goldman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Premium Movie Partnership, Adelaide Festival Corporation, South Australian Film Corporation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Tidy Town Pictures, Mark Lazarus and Paul Goldman

results.title: Australian reporter
results.brief_description: Magazine film comprising three items: Asian concert in Sydney at the Conservatorium of Music, asian students present a concert in aid of the Royal Blind Society; Young farmers, this movement introduces boys and girls to the science (and chores) of modern farming; Radio Australia, this international station uses experts from overseas and well-stocked libraries to maintain world-wide appeal. No other credits available.
